results.title: You Must Remember This
results.creator_credit: Vivid Pictures, Susan MacKinnon and Helen Bowden
results.brief_description: Alzheimer’s disease is very common, mysterious and fatal. This film follows the course of the disease from diagnosis to death. It looks at the subtle, early signs of Alzheimer’s disease and the slow loss of language, memory and skills. It looks at what is known about its causes, current treatments and where the hopes for a cure lie.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vivid Pictures, Susan MacKinnon and Helen Bowden

results.title: You Might Think You're Superior (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Students of various racial groups confront the racism they deal with daily. Perhaps schools often reinforce racism rather than help fight it? After a group of black high school students witness a disturbing incident one of the students describes what she saw. She claims police blamed a black boy for breaking a window when they had no proof it was him. She said there were five white boys and 3 black boys present and even when a white lady told them it wasn’t his fault they took no notice. When the students told the principal what happened he told them not to bother because they couldn’t fight it.

results.title: You might as well live
results.creator_credit: Fortian Productions, Con Anemogiannis and Judy Menczel
results.brief_description: ‘You might as well live’ is an excellent documentary on the subject of youth suicide in Australia. The film examines why Australia has such a high youth suicide rate and what can be done about it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fortian Productions, Con Anemogiannis and Judy Menczel

results.title: You keep juggling
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
One of a series of films that examines the history of immigration to Australia. This film discusses the assimilation of different cultures. Migrants speak of their experience as young people assimilation in Australia. For many there has been the conflict of finding a balance of identity between their parent’s home country values and Australian values.

results.title: You Just Don't Realise
results.creator_credit: Philippe de Montignie and Eyewitness News
results.brief_description: In Australia, where there is one vehicle for every three people, road accidents have reached epidemic proportions with 4,000 people dying each year. The trauma of the accidents themselves is only eclipsed by the trauma of the chain of events that follow. Highly graphic scenes of car accidents in this film make viewing unsuitable for sensitive people, and preview is strongly recommended

results.title: You jump, you fly: a multicultural textile project linking health and art
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australia Council and Luigi Acquisto
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
At the Coburg Community Health Centre, Anne Marie Power, textile artist, talks about groups of women that were linked together through a textile project. The common theme revolved around their houses and lives, and the women were able to develop skills which had previously been undervalued. The aim was to increase the self-awareness and self-esteem of the participants thus resulting in better health. The women with well-developed skills taught the others so a sense of group was developed.
results.title_for_label: You jump, you fly: a multicultural textile project linking health and art

results.title: You haven't changed a bit
results.creator_credit: Teleketics, Karl Holtsnider and Bruce Baker
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a young couple who after a quarrel take separate vacations at their respective parents’ homes. In the process they discover that despite their past associations their real identity lies in their relationship with each other.

results.title: You have struck a rock
results.brief_description: ‘You have touched a woman, you have struck a rock!’ was the cry in 1956 when 20,000 women occupied Union Buildings, the seat of the all-white South African government, to protest against the issuing of passes to black women. The film recreates this anti-apartheid womens’ campaign using a collage of rare photographs, newsreel footage and recent interviews with women involved.
results.description: ‘You have touched a woman, you have struck a rock!’ was the cry in 1956 when 20,000 women occupied Union Buildings, the seat of the all-white South African government, to protest against the issuing of passes to black women. The film recreates this anti-apartheid womens’ campaign using a collage of rare photographs, newsreel footage and recent interviews with women involved.
